SENT.plain: A 41-year-old Asian-Indian male presented with recurrent episodes of jaundice over the past six months
Physical examination was normal, barring mild icterus
Further evaluation yielded a diagnosis of severe nutritional vitamin B12 deficiency
Indirect hyperbilirubinemia was ascribed to ineffective erythropoiesis
Underlying Gilbert's syndrome was ruled out by provocative testing with lipid-restricted diet
Presentation of severe vitamin B12 deficiency with isolated hyperbilirubinemia without concomitant major haematologic or neurologic dysfunction is unusual and potentially underdiagnosed
Awareness of this possibility can permit early diagnosis of vitamin B12 deficiency and forestall development of severe haematologic and neurologic sequelae
